page.title: 17RELIGION IN KINGS LANGLEY
page.content: CHURCHES } {All Saints Church of England,}built of red brick & flint with a local stone dressing, has a Nave and Tower of 15th century origin and a 13th century piscina in the Chancel wall. Visitors come to see the carved marble tomb of Edmund of Langley, who}died at Langley Palace in 1402 and also the finely carved pulpit and alabaster reredos. An attractive hall was added in 1976. {Christ Church Baptist Chapel,}built in the Nap in 1939 to replace a very small mid-19th century Chapel which was east of the canal. {The Methodist Chapel}on the A41 north of the village was built in 1935. Although Methodists have been active in Kings Langley since 1870. {The Zion Chapel}in Waterside was built by the Strict Baptists in 1835.
